meanings.definition: Loss or lack of honor or respect
meanings.sent1: The soldier felt great dishonour after running away from the battle.
meanings.sent2: The community viewed the thief with dishonour for his actions.
meanings.sent3: It was a dishonour to the family name when the youngest son refused to help with chores.
meanings.sent4: The tarnished reputation brought a heavy cloud of dishonour upon the once-respected politician.
meanings.sent5: The dishonour of being caught cheating in the exam haunted him for years.

meanings.definition: To bring shame or disgrace upon
meanings.sent1: His reckless behavior would dishonour his family's name.
meanings.sent2: Gossiping about others can easily dishonour their reputation.
meanings.sent3: She joked that spilling coffee on her shirt would dishonour her outfit.
meanings.sent4: The graffiti on the monument seemed to dishonour the memory of those it honored.
meanings.sent5: The careless remarks made by the politician would dishonour his entire campaign.

meanings.definition: To fail to keep an agreement or promise
meanings.sent1: If you dishonour your commitment, others may not trust you again.
meanings.sent2: Breaking a promise can dishonour your word and integrity.
meanings.sent3: Forgetting to attend the meeting would dishonour the promise you made to your colleague.
meanings.sent4: The athlete feared that any injury might dishonour his pledge to compete in the championship.
meanings.sent5: To dishonour a vow is to weaken the bond of trust between two people.
